data.title: Utz by Chatwin Bruce, First Edition
data.meta_description: Utz by Chatwin. Bruce and a great selection of related books, art and collectibles available now at AbeBooks.co.uk.
data.text:
Hardcover. Condition: Very Good. Dust Jacket Condition: Near Fine. First Edition. First impression of the true first edition - the last book that was published in Chatwin's lifetime. ***Very good in black cloth-covered boards with gilt titles to the spine. The boards are quite clean with just light handling marks. No bumps. Corners sharp. Internally also very good with no inscriptions. Pages clean and bright with no foxing. Please note that there is some light creasing to the bottom edge of pp.53-63 (please see scans). Spine tight. ***In a near fine colour illustrated dustwrapper, which has not been price-clipped, retaining the original publisher's printed price of £9.95 net. No chips or tears. No creases. No fading. Dustwrapper bright. ***154 pages. 224mm x 142mm. ***'Harbouring his private collection of Meissen porcelains, Kasper Utz found a refuge from the horrors of the twentieth century. Compared with the exquisite reality of his figurines, rescued and safe in the illusionist city of Prague, the Gestapo and the Secret Police were to Utz as 'creatures of tinsel'. ***By modelling and remodelling the figure of Utz as each new detail about his life is unearthed, Bruce Chatwin offers an insight into the fictional process itself. The artistry, as always, is made to look simple, yet Chatwin's work stands out among contemporary writing as something valuable and rare.' (Quote taken from the front flap of the dustwrapper) ***'Charles Bruce Chatwin FRSL (13 May 1940 - 18 Jan 1989) was an English travel writer, novelist and journalist. His first book, "In Patagonia" (1977), established Chatwin as a travel writer, although he considered himself instead a storyteller, interested in bringing to light unusual tales. He won the James Tait Black Memorial Prize for his novel "On the Black Hill" (1982), while his novel "Utz" (1988) was shortlisted for the Man Booker Prize. In 2008 The Times ranked Chatwin as number 46 on their list of "50 Greatest British Writers Since 1945." (Wiki) ***A very good first impression of the first edition of Bruce Chatwin's novel "Utz". A nice reading copy. ***For all our books, postage is charged at cost, allowing for packaging: any shipping rates indicated on ABE are an average only: we will reduce the P & P charge where appropriate - please contact us for postal rates for heavier books and sets etc.

Hardcover. Condition: Very Good. Dust Jacket Condition: Very Good. First Edition. Utz by Bruce Chatwin.Kaspar Utz is the owner of a unique collection of Meissen porcelain. He lives in a two room flat in Prague in the 1970's. He should be trying to flee government persecution, but he feels bound to protect the collection. The book is a First US edition, First Printing. It is unfortunately, a remainder copy. There is also a gifting inscription to the half titlepage. Otherwise the book is in very good condition, some rubbing to edges, and slight discolouring to rear cover and shelfwear to note. The DW is also in very good condition. Some very slight shelf wear, tiniest chip to top of spine, and scratch on rear cover edge.

Hardcover. Condition: Near Fine. Dust Jacket Condition: Near Fine. First Edition. First impression of the true first edition - the last book that was published in Chatwin's lifetime. ***Near fine in black cloth-covered boards with gilt titles to the spine. The boards are clean and unmarked. No bumps or creases. Corners sharp. Binding straight with no reading lean. Spine tight. Page block edges clean with just some light foxing to the top edge. Internally also near fine with no inscriptions. Pages clean and bright. No creases or tears. Spine tight. ***In a near fine colour illustrated dustwrapper, that has not been price-clipped, retaining the original publisher's printed price of £9.95 net. No chips or tears. No creases. No fading. Dustwrapper bright. ***154 pages. 224mm x 142mm. ***'Harbouring his private collection of Meissen porcelains, Kasper Utz found a refuge from the horrors of the twentieth century. Compared with the exquisite reality of his figurines, rescued and safe in the illusionist city of Prague, the Gestapo and the Secret Police were to Utz as 'creatures of tinsel'. ***By modelling and remodelling the figure of Utz as each new detail about his life is unearthed, Bruce Chatwin offers an insight into the fictional process itself. The artistry, as always, is made to look simple, yet Chatwin's work stands out among contemporary writing as something valuable and rare.' (Quote taken from the front flap of the dustwrapper) ***'Charles Bruce Chatwin FRSL (13 May 1940 - 18 Jan 1989) was an English travel writer, novelist and journalist. His first book, "In Patagonia" (1977), established Chatwin as a travel writer, although he considered himself instead a storyteller, interested in bringing to light unusual tales. He won the James Tait Black Memorial Prize for his novel "On the Black Hill" (1982), while his novel "Utz" (1988) was shortlisted for the Man Booker Prize. In 2008 The Times ranked Chatwin as number 46 on their list of "50 Greatest British Writers Since 1945." (Wiki) ***A near fine first impression of the first edition of Bruce Chatwin's novel "Utz". A nice collectable copy. ***For all our books, postage is charged at cost, allowing for packaging: any shipping rates indicated on ABE are an average only: we will reduce the P & P charge where appropriate - please contact us for postal rates for heavier books and sets etc.

Hardcover. Condition: Very Good. Dust Jacket Condition: Very Good. 1st Edition. True first British printing with original unclipped jacket (£9.95). Jacket has minor patchy edge/shelf wear, a few small marks, pushing/creasing/wrinkling to/near front lower corner, the odd small rub/crease to edges, a little pushing/rubbing to head/tail of spine and to corners, a few small scratches, rubbing, the odd small mark/little dustiness/spot of foxing to reverse (white side) and a little creasing/minor foxing/odd small mark to front/back inner flaps. Boards are very good with a few small bumps/patchy rubbing to lower edges, bumping/creasing to front lower corner, minor pushing/bumping to other corners, a few small marks and minor pushing/rubbing to head/tail of spine. Pages are generally clean and the binding is tight. Top edge of pages have the odd very small mark/spots of foxing. Odd small mark/spot of foxing to page edges and bottoms. Pages slightly tanned. Very occasional small mark to pages. No other faults. All books described honestly and accurately. Paypal accepted.

Hard Back. Condition: Very Good. Dust Jacket Condition: Very Good. First Edition. 154 pages, Condition: Dust Jacket very good, uncut, minor scratch front. Black binding almost mint. Contents very good, clean copy almost mint, except for owner name & 1989 inside front cover. This story is based on Chatwin's experiences of working at Sotheby's and a collector, and is about Kasper Utz Harbouring his private collection of Meissen porcelains, that Utz found a refuge from the horrors of the twentieth century. Compared with the exquisite reality of his figurines, rescued and safe in the illusionist city of Prague, the Gestapo and the Secret Police were to Utz `creatures of tinsel'. It was the colourful Harlequin, `the Trickster', with whom nondescript Utz most identified. Utz too was adept at wriggling into positions of advantage, at outwitting authorities - and the love of his own Columbine was nearer at hand than he knew. By modelling and remodelling the figure of Utz as each new detail about his life is unearthed, Bruce Chatwin offers an insight into the fictional process itself. Utz was Chatwin's last novel, and was published in September 1988, it was shortlisted for the Booker Prize Chatwin was very ill . Size: 14.5 x 22cm Approx.

Jonathan Cape. UK. 1988. 'Utz' by Bruce Chatwin. This book is a first edition hardback with dustjacket. Please note: this is not an exlib book. It has at some early stage been laminated by a careful owner which has preserved the dustjacket very well. Bruce Chatwin was a gifted travel writer and for his book 'In Patagonia' he won the Hawthornden Prize and the E M Forster Award. This novel, 'Utz' was shortlisted for the Booker Prize. Bruce Chatwin died in France in 1989. The dustjacket is bright and glossy and not price clipped. Contents: there is an attractive bookplate to the rear of the front board, partially hidden by the inner flap. Light age stops to edge of text block otherwise the book very good. Smart black boards. Not exlib and packed and sent with care.
